{{Taxobox | image = cupreobrunneus.jpg | image_width = 234px | image_caption = A collection from [[Union City, California]] | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | phylum = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Agaricaceae]] | genus = ''[[Agaricus]]'' | species = '''''A. cupreobrunneus''''' | binomial = ''Agaricus cupreobrunneus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Julius Schäffer|Jul.Schäffer]] & Steer ex F.H.Møller) [[Albert Pilát|Pilát]] (1951) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Psalliota campestris'' var. ''cupreobrunnea'' Jul.Schäff. & Steer (1939)
''Psalliota campestris'' var. ''cupreobrunnea'' Jul.Schäff. & Steer ex F.H.Møller (1949)
''Psalliota cupreobrunnea'' Jul.Schäff. & Steer ex F.H.Møller (1950) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Agaricus cupreobrunneus'' | whichGills = free | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=ring | sporePrintColor=blackish-brown | howEdible=choice}} '''''Agaricus cupreobrunneus''''', commonly known as the '''brown field mushroom''', is an [[edible mushroom]] of the genus ''[[Agaricus]]''. ==Distribution and habitat== ''Agaricus cupreobrunneus'' tends to fruit in disturbed areas and grassy places, such as lawns, pastures, and roadsides. It can fruit by itself, gregariously, or in [[fairy ring]]s. ==Edibility== ''Agaricus cupreobrunneus'' is [[edible mushroom|edible]] and good. Its taste is comparable to that of ''[[Agaricus campestris]]'', but it is comparatively lacking in texture. ''Agaricus cupreobrunneus'' is not currently cultivated on a widespread basis, but is commonly eaten by collectors in the areas in which it grows. It does not contain the carcinogen [[agaritine]] which appears in many other members of the genus [[Agaricus]]. ==Similar species== ''Agaricus. cupreobrunneus'' is similar in general appearance to a number of other ''Agaricus'' species, especially to ''A. campestris''. It also bears strong similarities to ''[[Agaricus porphyrocephalus|A. porphyrocephalus]]'', ''[[Agaricus rutilescens|A. rutilescens]]'', and ''[[Agaricus argenteus|A. argenteus]]''. The only potential lookalikes of ''A. cupreobrunneus'' that are [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] are yellow- or red-staining, or occur in much different habitats. ==See also== *[[List of Agaricus species|List of ''Agaricus'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Agaricus_cupreo-brunneus.html |title=California Fungi—''Agaricus cupreo-brunneus'' |author=Wood M, Stevens F |accessdate=2011-04-15 |publisher=MykoWeb |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514041055/http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Agaricus_cupreo-brunneus.html |archivedate=2011-05-14 |url-status=dead }} {{cite book |author=Arora D. |title=Mushrooms Demystified: a Comprehensive Guide to the Fleshy Fungi |publisher=Ten Speed Press |location=Berkeley, California |year=1986 |page=319 |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=292257 |title=''Agaricus cupreobrunneus'' (Jul. Schäff. & Steer ex F.H. Møller) Pilát 1951 |format=International Mycological Association |work=MycoBank |accessdate=2011-04-16}} {{cite journal|author=Stijve, Pittet|year=2000|title= Absence of agaritine in Pleurotus species and in other cultivated and wild-growing mushrooms not belonging to the genus Agaricus.|journal=Deutsche Lebensmittel-Rundschau|volume=96|issue=7|pages=251–254}} }} ==External links== *{{IndexFungorum|292257}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q4672758}} [[Category:Agaricus|cupreobrunneus]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1939]]
